body_html:
A quick search showed that 'boolean' is defined in Windows SDK header rpcndr.h.

Actually, it looks like jpeg-turbo does handle this case in in win/jconfig.h.in:

#ifndef RPCNDR_H /* don't conflict if rpcndr.h already read */
typedef unsigned char boolean;
#endif
#define HAVE_BOOLEAN

One of the following is possible:

  1. Bazel does not generate the proper version of jconfig.h for Windows.
  2. The JCONFIG_INCLUDED macro is defined somewhere by Bazel, i.e. at the top of jpeglib.h:

#ifndef JCONFIG_INCLUDED /* in case jinclude.h already did /
#include "jconfig.h" / widely used configuration options */
#endif
body_text:
A quick search showed that 'boolean' is defined in Windows SDK header rpcndr.h.
Actually, it looks like jpeg-turbo does handle this case in in win/jconfig.h.in:
#ifndef RPCNDR_H		/* don't conflict if rpcndr.h already read */
typedef unsigned char boolean;
#endif
#define HAVE_BOOLEAN
One of the following is possible:

Bazel does not generate the proper version of jconfig.h for Windows.
The JCONFIG_INCLUDED macro is defined somewhere by Bazel, i.e. at the top of jpeglib.h:

#ifndef JCONFIG_INCLUDED        /* in case jinclude.h already did /
#include "jconfig.h"            / widely used configuration options */
#endif
body:
A quick search showed that 'boolean' is defined in Windows SDK header rpcndr.h.

Actually, it looks like jpeg-turbo does handle this case in in [win/jconfig.h.in](https://github.com/libjpeg-turbo/libjpeg-turbo/blob/master/win/jconfig.h.in):

#ifndef __RPCNDR_H__		/* don't conflict if rpcndr.h already read */
typedef unsigned char boolean;
#endif
#define HAVE_BOOLEAN

One of the following is possible:

1. Bazel does not generate the proper version of jconfig.h for Windows.
2. The JCONFIG_INCLUDED macro is defined somewhere by Bazel, i.e. at the top of jpeglib.h:

#ifndef JCONFIG_INCLUDED        /* in case jinclude.h already did */
#include "jconfig.h"            /* widely used configuration options */
#endif
